trial_identification.studytitle: Video assisted laryngoscopy with cricoid pressure in patients using a C-Mac.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Blinded off line assessment of the effects of cricoid pressure with video assisted laryngoscopy in patients using a C-Mac,

conditions.healthcondition: quality of the larygoscopic view with a video assisted laryngoscope during application of cricoid pressure

interventions.interventions: Phase 1: laryngoscopy without cricoid pressure; 5 seconds Phase 2: with cricoid pressure without video assist; 5 seconds and Phase 3: with cricoid pressure with video assist.10 seconds

primaryOutcome.outcome: comparison of laryngoscopic view with application of cricoid pressure assisted by video scope with cricoid applied without video assistance of person applying cricoid pressure. This is to be done using the Cormack and Lahane grading system that is in common use throughout the anaesthetic community

secondaryOutcome.outcome: comparison of quality of laryngoscopic view when cricoid is applied compared to prior to application. This is to be done using the Cormack and Lahane grading system that is in common use throughout the anaesthetic community

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: patient requiring elective intubation for surgery
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: requiring rapid sequence induction, unable to give consent, unable to communicate in english.

trial_design.concealment: all aptients who accept enrollment will have the three phases of laryngoscopy without cricoid pressure, with cricoid pressure without video assist and then with video assist.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study seeks to determine the effect of application of cricoid pressure on the laryngoscopic view using a cMac video laryngoscope and secondly to assess if whether having the person applying the cricoid viewing the video feed assists in improving the laryngoscopic view.
ethicsAndSummary.publication:
Published Loughnan TE, Gunasekera E, Tan TP.
Anaesth Intensive Care. 2012 Jan;40(1):128-30.
PMID:22313072[PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE
